p: The global response to COVID‐19 has taught us something else: In times of great danger, we can (but may not) make substantial changes to our lifestyles. Now, a year into the pandemic, there are glimmers of hope among the grave uncertainties—vaccines have been developed, and there may be a time, after this period of terrible loss, when we emerge, battered and blinking, into the world. Pandemics have often triggered major social and political shifts. Changing system constraints lead one to different answers to the 4 sustainability questions (Kapustka et al. 2013) as we enter into a brave new world. Do we want to rush to return to an unattainable, and unsustainable, status quo, or will we use this time as an opportunity to re‐think the societies and world we want to live in and leave to our children? We have the opportunity, and the tools, to help frame, inform, and to some extent, guide such decisions. Chapman ( 2016) told us to “be virtuous and serve science well.” If we do this, rising above current extreme and polarizing political discourses, we can also serve society, navigating the treacherous path ahead of us all.
